Description: Cypriot terracotta figure of robed man with beard and headdress. Flat mould-made ‘Asiatic’, or ‘Assyrian’ type. Pressed into one-piece mould. Robe, face and headdress painted red, beard and details painted black. Pale buff/grey fabric with fine black and white inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ16 or 17
Curator's comments: Possibly from the same mould as eroded piece from Naukratis in Bolton Museum (1911.44.29). Asiatic’ looking male figurines date to between the mid 7th and the late 6th century BC, with very close parallels from Cyprus, probably from the Arsos workshops (Karageorghis 1995, 19-21, Type I(ii)38, pl. 9.3). V. Karageorghis argues the ‘Assyrian’ look may coincide with Assyrian domination of Cyprus during the 7th century BC (Karageorghis 1995, 21). Four other similar pieces were found in the temple of Aphrodite in Naukratis (GR1949,0808.1, GR1949,0808.2; GR1949,0808.3; AES1911,0710.102) with other Cypriot pieces (AES1911,0710.92-106; Bailey 2008, 186) marked “T ΑΦ16” or “T ΑΦ17” (Temple of Aphrodite, Findspot 16 or 17) from a 26th Dynasty context. Karageorghis, V. 1995. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. IV. The Cypro-Archaic Period small male figurines. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.037) (Phase 1)
